content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a good problem for Clash of Code. The statement is clear and the examples seem to be simple enough to realize what you have to do. The problem might seem a little difficult, but I've seen harder problems in clashes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's indeed kind of on the edge regarding the difficulty, but I made a mistake of going for shortest right from the beginning (so it was so so in 15 minutes). Aiming for fastest would be OK. And I like the idea and it was fun solving it, thanks!

I would suggest reworking the statement a little.

It may be confusing who "the user" is. Maybe it's better to change it to just "Output all the words that fit constraints/filters/requests".

"If command is-" lines don't look good. It's better to structure it like a switch-case. Exp:
`If the command is:
    'start' - check whether ...
    'end' - check whether...
...`

Also, an example from the statement is practically useless since it repeats information from the first test combined with some Input description. You need to explain how come output is what it is if you want to help people better understand how it works. You can also just erase it since the statement and tests explain everything pretty well already.

Validator 2 needs to have 2 lines in the output.

Otherwise, pretty good.

If you change anything, please ping me

I quite like the idea.
I could solve the problem in 5 minutes so I think the difficulty is okay.
However, I have to side with Allis on the issue of 'y'.
In English, "y" can be either a vowel or a consonant depending on the word.
As you have included English words in your test cases, it may be better not to consider "y" a vowel at all as I fear this could confuse English speakers. (Remember that validators are not visible during a clash so it wouldn't be possible for the player to check whether y really is a vowel or not)
Also I think the statement could use a little rephrasing but overall this is promising clash.

The problem description uses "consonants", some of the tests use "consonant" while one uses "consonants" and in all the confusion, your code misses it (as does Andre's below) because it falls through the else statement. (Other uses might not be so lucky.) I would suggest picking one or the other.

My other issue is with the time limit. I'm an experienced programmer and I think most people are going to have trouble finishing this under 5 minutes.
I quite like this one, but you might want to be explicit about which letters should be considered vowels, since technically the Ys in both "gym" and "why" are vowels.

I see you took this into account, but probably it would be better to explicitly *disqualify* Y as opposed to explicitly allowing it, since it's not always a vowel. With the current test cases, it doesn't matter, but if they contained words like "yellow" or "your" (where Y isn't a vowel), this problem becomes considerably harder.
I like it though and I upvoted. I think it just needs a touch more work.
This problem is already really hard and it needs to be solvable in 5 minutes, so I think I will keep it simple.
